C_9793109d99064ce89c29c41aca07e1e0_q#1.text: Flour (+ water, either directly or from other ingredients such as egg white) gives the pastry structure
As you knead the flour, the gluten network develops and results in elasticity
The thin fat layers are impermeable, so water steam gets trapped and exercise pressure upwards, lifting the pastry up
When cooked, water evaporates from the dough leaving a rigid gluten skeleton
Fat does not mix with water and thus stay in blobs in between the gluten network
For this reason, you often see in recipes for shortcrust to avoid overmixing the fat
This weakens the gluten structure, making the pastry crumble
Quoting @GdD in the comments, the punchline is:more fat = crumblier, less fat has more structure
